transcripts.text: Now the problem that the West has is inequality.  When you talk about people waking up, people are increasingly waking up.
Because of what happens to them.  It has nothing to... And that's my problem...
So you're saying it's not benevolent?

No.  It's my problem when I talk to people in UK, for example.  I understand grievances that British people have.  I understand that you have many poor people now in your own society.  Some of your children are hungry.  Some.  It is horrible.

Yes, it's terrible.  But are people rebelling against the system only because what is happening to them individually?  Or are they thinking about this entire world being run by maniacs from London and from Washington and from Paris?  Yes.  Would they sacrifice again the rest of the world if their personal lives would improve?  I doubt it.  I hope they would want the entire world to improve, but very often it feels that they are talking about their waking up is just addressing the grievances they have towards the regime.  Basically what happened is that what is done to the English people now was always done to the colonists.  Much worse things were done to the colonies, but essentially this is what was done to the colonies.  And they never cared.  But now the system went mad and they are starting to do what they never did in the past.  They start to treat their own people in London, in Manchester, in Glasgow, they start to treat their own people as they used to treat people somewhere in Karachi.
So the rent seekers have turned on their own people.

Yes, this is absolutely mad.  And the people in UK who are not used to being treated like this are of course rebelling and they don't understand what's going on, how dare they treat them like this.  But what I don't hear in the London pub or in London tube or on London street is that they are actually doing to us what we were doing to the rest of the world for centuries.
